a record of all the different medications a patient has been prescribed, including a unique identifier for each medication order.
information regarding patient messages in MyChart for specific clinical encounters, including encounter dates and message identifiers.
information about patients' primary care providers, including their ID, effective dates of care, and specialty details.
information on a patient's preferred pharmacies, including identifiers and names.
information about where patients primarily receive their care, including when this information became valid.
a list of health issues and their unique identifiers for each patient.
information on the patients' most recently chosen pharmacies, including pharmacy IDs and names.
emergency contact addresses for patients, with each row detailing a specific line of an address for a particular contact.
information about where a patient's emergency contacts or family members live.
historical information on the different types of relationships a patient has had, including when those relationships began and ended.
contact information and relationships for patients, including names, addresses, phone numbers, and whether they are associated at the patient level.
contact details and relationships for patients, including names, addresses, phone numbers, and their relation to the patient.
information about specific situations where the records of a patient's contacts or relationships are applicable.
email contact information for the patient's associates, such as whether an email is their primary contact method.
information on the languages spoken or understood by the patient's emergency contacts or family members.
phone numbers and types for the contacts of patients, and indicates which one is the primary contact number.
information about the special needs of individuals who are in contact with patients, such as family members or caregivers.
information about a patient's allergy data as reviewed and confirmed by the patient, including allergen names and patient responses.
information on health issues input by patients during their visit using a self-service kiosk or online patient portal, including their responses and any additional details they provided.
information about the patient's diagnosed conditions that prompted an outpatient visit.
information on a patient's social history as documented during a healthcare visit.
information about whether patient notes have been converted to a Unique Contact Number (UCN) format, including details of each encounter and associated notes.
information about medical laboratories or healthcare facilities that perform clinical tests, including their names, directors, locations, contact information, and regulatory compliance identifiers.
individuals' unique preferences that are not related to communication.
information about the different body systems associated with patients' health problems as recorded in their medical records.
details about patients' insurance benefits explanations for specific healthcare service transactions, including amounts, codes, and comments.
information about patients' insurance benefits for each healthcare service transaction, including coverage amounts, payments, denial codes, and related comments.
identification information for each unique prescription order, including order number, line item details, and the prescription ID itself.
information on all health issues and conditions associated with each patient, categorized by the type of record.
the history and changes of a patient's health issues, including when they were first noted, any updates, who made the changes, and the status of the problem (like if it's chronic or resolved).

details about patients' health issues, including when they were first reported, their current status (like active, resolved, or deleted), and whether they're chronic or visible to patients on their online portal.
historical records of when and by whom a patient's problem list was reviewed, including the dates, times, and related patient encounters.
updates to patients' health issues, including when and by whom the updates were made.
the most recent responses to patient questionnaires, including when they were completed and the identifier for the specific patient encounter related to the questionnaire.
patient questionnaire answers that have yet to be submitted, including patient identifiers and the status of their completion.
information about the current status and relevant actions of medical billing claims, including unique identifiers and dates of correspondence.

information on the process of matching and verifying health insurance claims with payments, including each claim's unique ID, invoice number, status, payer details, billing amounts, and relevant dates.
data about the process and status of insurance claims over time, including submission amounts, payer information, and related actions and reasons.
information about appointments linked to referral records, including the dates, types of services, and the number of times the patient has been seen under this referral.
information about patient referrals between different healthcare organizations, including their current status and identifying details.
authorization and certification details for patient referrals, including associated comments and benefit information.
information about patients' diagnoses associated with their medical referrals, including a unique ID for the referral and a sequence number for multiple diagnoses.
records of updates to patient referral details, including who made the change, when, and what was changed.

information on patient referrals, including ID numbers, status, provider details, specialty category, type and reason for referral, start and expiration dates, visit authorizations, coverage details, scheduling, and decision-making aspects.
written comments and details related to a patient's referral, including who wrote each note and when it was created.

details about each procedure required for a patient's referral, including the sequence, procedure identification, units requested and approved, coverage information, and any relevant authorization comments.
information about why patients were referred, including a unique identifier for each referral and categorized reasons.
information about who is recommending patients, including the identification and name of the referring doctor or entity.
codes that indicate whether a healthcare claim is related to work or an accident.
customizable preferences for health screening test reports.
information on patient follow-up activities and the associated test results for a specific encounter.
a list of geographical areas associated with referrals, including which area was designated for each referral based on department, location, vendor, or provider.
information on who (physician or radiologist) signed an imaging order and when it was signed.
information on medication packaging codes used in the United States.
information about different pharmacies, including unique identifiers and their names.
basic information about social determinants of health for patients, including when the data was documented, the severity level, and unique identifiers for each entry.
information about different areas of patients' life circumstances that affect their health, such as housing or food access, including identifiers and naming details.
information about the insurance benefits related to specific health services, including copay, deductible, coinsurance, and the type of service covered.
pre-written blocks of clinical text used for documentation and patient communication, including their unique identifiers and names.
information about a patient's ability to perform daily activities recorded during their social history review in a healthcare visit.
information about patients' social habits such as tobacco and alcohol use, substance abuse, sexual activity, and contraception preferences documented during their history encounters.
information on what type of biological specimen was collected for a laboratory order, using standardized medical codes to describe the source.
information about the types of medical specimens (like blood, tissue, etc.) linked with their respective standardized SNOMED codes.
records of patients' past surgical procedures as documented during various clinical encounters.
detailed information on individual service lines from medical claims, including dates of service, procedure codes, provider details, and amounts billed and paid.
detailed records of payments, including each transaction's unique identifier, associated line information, and specific actions taken during payment processing.
information on different task templates used in a clinical setting, including their unique identifiers and names.
responses to safety checks performed before medical procedures, including details about each check, such as date, time, and unique identifiers for the records.
safety checks performed before medical procedures and their verification details for a particular patient.
information about the medical treatments ordered during each patient's hospital visit, including unique identifiers and contact dates.
information about the healthcare professionals involved in a patient's care, including their roles, specialties, and the duration of their involvement.
information about the medical conditions linked to each patient billing transaction, including the date, service area, and specific diagnosis.
information about individual medication packages including their unique codes and associated dosing details linked to specific healthcare billing transactions.
information about medication identification and dosages linked to specific billing records.
information on specific medical conditions linked to individual billing items in a financial record for healthcare services.
additional modification details associated with healthcare service charges, such as special conditions affecting the service billing.
the history of updates made to individual items in the hospital's billing system.
information about every billing area in the healthcare system, including a unique ID and the name for each billing area.
information on notes from medical records linked to specific patients for health information exchange purposes.
